title: 'Ghost Recon Breakpoint' is a letdown -- with some bright spots: What to know
text:
Your team of ghosts have to deal with a dangerous island (Photo: Ubisoft)

"Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Breakpoint" starts with a simple mission. You have to find your downed teammates and figure out how things went so wrong, so quickly.

Your Ghost team, a U.S. Special Forces group, is in trouble and confused. But it still your job to sort things out.

That's the backdrop under which you'll play "Breakpoint," the latest installment in the Ghost Recon video game series. The game was released on Oct. 4 for PlayStation 4, Xbox One and PC ($59.99-up, for ages 17-up).

You play as Nomad, leader of the Ghost team sent to the island of Auroa. It's a vast locale filled with gear to choose from and enemies to shoot. It's also kind of boring.

Here is what to know about the game.

It’s a victim of its own open-world design

A strength of "Breakpoint" is that you can go anywhere on the island. You can get there via any number of vehicles and perfectly placed quick travel spots. You can even do missions in any order you choose. It's a refreshing sense of freedom.

The problem? "Breakpoint" somehow manages to make it all too bland.

After more than 35 hours of playing the game, I pondered why I found most of the single-player experience to be forgettable despite some good development ideas.

I think it's because the developers spent so much time building a potentially exhilarating world that they ran out of time to make it fun to navigate. The missions, for example, provide variety in terms of how you get to your missions.

But once you get there, you'll fight a repetitious cadre of enemies and go through similar sequences of steps – from how you enter the area to how you take down the enemies –before you can investigate the latest development.

Ghost Recon Breakpoints map is beautiful (Photo: Ubisoft)

Multiplayer: promising, but needs work

It’s the multiplayer mode where I believe the game could have some sustainable shine to it, but even it needs help.

Join the current version of Ghost War to spawn into a team of four players who battle it out in a couple of different modes. Your gear, rating, and overall loadout cross over from the story campaign. There is some balancing to make multiplayer matches more evenly fought, but your character is largely here as in the main game. The maps are small, which is perfect because players tend to camp. These are all good things.

Where the PvP fails is in the lack of variety in game modes and the excruciating wait times between rounds and matches. It’s ridiculous how long players must wait. The wait between rounds can be up to five minutes, which at times was longer than the round itself. It all just bogs the multiplayer down.

The amount of gear and content is impressive

What kind of weapon do you prefer? What attachment? What about devices and support gear? "Breakpoint" has you covered in a big way. One of the game's few redeeming qualities is the robust library of weapons and gadgets to try out.

I would recommend equipping your rifles with grenade launchers as soon as you can – something I took far too long to do. And, for sure, I would suggest buying an armored vehicle when you can, too, because it increases the fun factor – you can run over enemies and bash into enemy vehicles.

Take advantage of the quality of life features

Ghost Recond Breakpoint lets make adjustments at campsites (Photo: Ubisoft)

What’s easy to lose in mountains of gears and content is that the developers were gracious enough to make things easier with the campgrounds scattered through the island.

You’ll unlock these camping sites as you play and should use them frequently. You can adjust the gear you’ve picked up, change your skill tree, and search the in-game shop.

This is vitally important in a game because the game puts such an emphasis on your gear score and being able to travel between missions. Buy new equipment and choose your transportation from the camp. Plus you're able to carry a large amount of gear around as you play, which is a huge thing for gamers that developers often limit.
